title: Severe Thermal Burns
diagnosis_topic: 40% total body surface area flame burns with inhalation injury
setup_script: “A 27-year-old woman is rescued from a house fire. She has deep partial-thickness and full-thickness burns on her torso, arms, and face. She is confused and coughing up soot. How would you proceed in her initial evaluation and management?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “You note singed nasal hairs, carbonaceous sputum, and hoarseness. What would you like to do next?”
“Airway edema progresses rapidly, resulting in failed intubation attempt. The patient desaturates to 75%. What is your next step?”
“Airway secured successfully. Oxygen saturation improves to 98% on ventilator settings.”
“BP 110/70 mmHg, HR 120 bpm, RR 26/min, Temp 36.5 °C, SpO₂ 94%.”
“Using the rule of nines, estimated burn size is approximately 40% TBSA (anterior torso 18%, both arms 18%, face 4%).”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates fluid resuscitation using Parkland formula
dynamic_flow.reply: “Calculated requirement is 9.6 L over 24 hours for a 60 kg patient. You begin half over the first 8 hours. What monitoring will you use?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays or provides inadequate resuscitation
dynamic_flow.reply: “Urine output declines to 10 mL/hr, heart rate rises to 140 bpm, blood pressure drops to 90/60 mmHg.”
“Urine output can now be monitored. Target is 0.5 mL/kg/hr. Current urine output is 30 mL/hr.”
“Result returns elevated at 25%. What is your management?”
“Carboxyhemoglobin level decreases, patient remains hemodynamically stable.”
“IV opioids are administered. Pain is improved, vitals remain stable.”
“Circumferential burns on the chest wall are limiting expansion, and peak inspiratory pressures on the ventilator are rising. What do you want to do?”
“Transfer is arranged for definitive burn care, debridement, and grafting.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident addresses tetanus and nutrition
dynamic_flow.reply: “Tetanus prophylaxis administered and nutrition plan initiated with high-protein diet recommendations.”

critical_decision_points: Early airway assessment and protection in inhalation injury
Accurate estimation of burn size and calculation of fluid resuscitation (Parkland formula)
Recognition and management of carbon monoxide poisoning
Indications for and performance of escharotomy
Pain control, tetanus prophylaxis, and nutritional support
Transfer to a burn center for definitive care

anchors.1: Fails to recognize severe burns or inhalation injury
anchors.2: Delayed or incomplete recognition, misses key features
anchors.3: Recognizes severe burns but misses elements of inhalation injury or systemic impact
anchors.4: Accurately identifies severe thermal burns, inhalation injury, and their implications
anchors.5: Rapidly identifies full spectrum of burn pathology, articulates comprehensive differential and diagnostic plan

anchors.1: Fails to prioritize airway or resuscitation, unsafe management
anchors.2: Recognizes urgency but delays critical interventions
anchors.3: Initiates management but misses timing or key steps
anchors.4: Prioritizes airway, resuscitation, and transfer appropriately
anchors.5: Anticipates complications, coordinates multidisciplinary care, executes timely decisions

anchors.1: Disorganized, unclear, lacks engagement with team
anchors.2: Provides information but lacks clarity or structure
anchors.3: Communicates findings and plan clearly but without refinement
anchors.4: Clear, logical, empathetic communication with patient and team
anchors.5: Exemplary communication, anticipates information needs, concise and compassionate

anchors.1: Lacks knowledge of burn management principles
anchors.2: Identifies some management steps but with major omissions
anchors.3: Describes key steps with minor gaps
anchors.4: Comprehensive knowledge of fluid resuscitation, airway management, and escharotomy
anchors.5: Mastery of burn management, including evidence-based operative and perioperative considerations

anchors.3: Professional behavior but requires prompting for self-reflection
anchors.4: Consistently respectful, accountable, receptive to feedback
anchors.5: Role model professionalism, humility, and ethical conduct

resident_feedback_template:
StrengthsYou demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by promptly recognizing the need for airway protection and fluid resuscitation. Your clinical judgment in addressing inhalation injury and initiating transfer to a burn center showed good prioritization. Communication of your plan was clear and structured.
Areas for ImprovementEarlier recognition and decisive management of the airway would improve outcomes in burn patients with inhalation injury. Consider reinforcing knowledge on monitoring adequacy of resuscitation and recognizing when escharotomy is required.
Suggested Reading Topics- Inhalation Injury and Airway Management (SCORE)- Parkland Formula and Burn Resuscitation (ACS/ASE Review Manual)- Escharotomy Indications and Technique (SCORE Curriculum)
